snippet: Experts predict an increase in lawsuits in states that are no longer covered under the Voting Rights Act after the Supreme Court ruling last month.
abstract: State officials across the South are aggressively moving ahead with new laws requiring voters to show photo identification at the polls after Supreme Court decision struck down portion of the Voting Rights Act; Republicans who control state legislatures say such laws are needed to prevent voter fraud, but Democrats argue such fraud is rare, and fear proposed changes will make it harder for poor voters and members of minorities, many of whom vote Democratic.
lead_paragraph: Experts predict an increase in lawsuits in states that are no longer covered under the Voting Rights Act after the Supreme Court ruling last month.

headline.main: After Ruling, States Rush to Enact Voting Laws
headline.print_headline: After Ruling, States Rush To Enact Voting Laws
